April 2009 |legislation_begin= Local Government Act 1972

|start_date1= and 1 April 1965 |start_date2= some earlier (see text)
|start_date3= |population_range= 25,000â1.1 million |area_range= |type=
Metropolitan (36) |type1= Non-metropolitan two-tier (201) |type2= Unitary
authority (55) |type3= London borough (32) |type4= sui generis (2) |status= City
|status1= Royal borough |status2= Borough |name= Districts (England) |category=
Local government districts }} The 'districts of England' are a level of
subnational division of England used for the purposes of local government. As
the structure of local government in England is not uniform, there are currently
four principal types of district-level subdivision. There are a total of 326
districts made up of 36 metropolitan boroughs, 32 London boroughs, 201 non-
metropolitan districts, 55 unitary authorities, as well as the City of London
and the Isles of Scilly which are also districts, but do not correspond to any
of these categories. Some districts are styled as boroughs, cities, or royal
boroughs; these are purely honorific titles, and do not alter the status of the
district. All boroughs and cities, and a few districts, are led by a mayor who
in most cases is a ceremonial figure elected by the district council, but â
after local government reform â is occasionally a directly elected mayor who
makes most of the policy decisions instead of the council.
